headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jennifer and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the BlackRock Inc. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference. Our host for today's call will be Chairman and Chief Exe
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Jennifer and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the BlackRock Inc. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference. 
Our host for today's call will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Laurence D. Fink; Chief Financial Officer, Gary S. Shedlin; President, Robert S. Kapito; and General Counsel, Matthew Mallow. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Mallow, you may begin your conference.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much. Good morning, everyone. I'm Matt Mallow, the General Counsel of BlackRock. Before Larry and Gary make their remarks, let me remind you that during the course of this call, we may make a number of forward-looking statements and call your
componenttext:
Thanks very much. Good morning, everyone. I'm Matt Mallow, the General Counsel of BlackRock. Before Larry and Gary make their remarks, let me remind you that during the course of this call, we may make a number of forward-looking statements and call your attention to the fact that BlackRock's actual results may, of course, differ from those stated. 
As you know, BlackRock has filed and will file reports with the SEC, which lists some of the factors that may cause the results of BlackRock to differ materially from what we say today. And BlackRock assumes no duty, and will not undertake to update any forward-looking statements. 
So with that, that's begin the call. Gary?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you Matt, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to be here to present the results for the second quarter of 2015. Before I turn it over to Larry to offer his comments, I'll review our quarterly financial performance and business results.  A
componenttext:
Thank you Matt, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to be here to present the results for the second quarter of 2015. 
Before I turn it over to Larry to offer his comments, I'll review our quarterly financial performance and business results.  As usual, I'll be focusing primarily on our as adjusted results. 
Our second quarter results, again, demonstrates the value of the investments we've made to assemble the industry's broadest and most global suite of active and index investment offerings and to deliver differentiated customize investment solutions to our clients.  Our business model was purposely designed to deliver differentiated results in the current volatile market environment. 
Second quarter revenue of $2.9 billion was 5%  higher than a year ago while operating income of $1.2 billion was 10% higher on a year-over-year basis. 
Earnings per share of $4.96 were up 1% compared to a year ago, reflecting lower nonoperating results and a higher normalized tax rate in the current quarter. 
Nonoperating results for the quarter reflects $3 million of net investment losses, largely driven by net losses on unhedged or partially hedged multi-asset and fixed income investments. Recall that our first quarter nonoperative results included a onetime gain of $40 million related to the fair value of our pre-existing interest in BlackRock Kelso Capital Advisors. 
Our as adjusted tax rate for the quarter was 30.1% compared to an as adjusted tax rate of 24.8% in last year's second quarter that benefited from several favorable nonrecurring items.  We currently estimate that 30% remains a reasonable projected tax run rate for the remainder of 2015. 
Second quarter long term net outflows of $7 billion reflected elevated market volatility as $24 billion of net new business from active in iShares products was more than offset by $31 billion of low fee Institutional Index outflows. While this resulted in an all organic acid growth rate significantly less than our target for the quarter, our annualized long term organic-based fee growth rate was in excess of  5% as each of our retail and iShares businesses, along with the active component of our Institutional business generated positive organic growth in the second quarter. 
Over the last 12 months, notwithstanding the increasingly unsettled microenvironments, BlackRock's highly diversified platform generated approximately $180 billion of long term net new business, representing a 4% long term organic AUM growth rate and a 6% organic-based fee growth rate as faster growth in our higher fee channels continues to contribute to a favorable overall change in our base fee mix. 
We previously discussed the importance of organic-based fee growth rate to our business and we're always thinking about ways to improve our disclosure to help investors and analysts better understand our business. 
As you will note on Page 2 of our earnings supplement, we have now expanded our financial disclosure to include organic-based fee growth on a trailing 12-month basis to better reflect this positive mix change over time. 
Second quarter-based fees rose 4$ year-over-year as the average AUM increased due to organic growth of market depreciation despite $191 billion of negative FX impact associated with dollar appreciation against foreign currencies over the last 12 months. 
On a constant-currency basis, we estimate that quarter-based fees were approximately 8% year-over-year. 
Sequentially, based fees were up 6%, reflecting organic-based fee growth, the effect of 1 additional day in the quarter and seasonally higher securities lending fees. 
Performance fees of $136 million were up 18% from the year ago reflecting strong alpha generation in certain equity products that locked annually in the second quarter. 
BlackRock Solutions revenue of $161 million was up 10%, both year-over-year and sequentially. Our Aladdin business, which represented 80% of BRS revenue in the quarter were 14% year-over-year and 2% sequentially. The year-over-year increase is driven by several sizeable clients going live on the Aladdin platform over the last 12 months.  We continue to see strong market demand for global investment platform consolidation and multi-risk solutions. 
Revenue in our Financial Markets Advisory business was flat year-over-year reflecting the positive impact of residual disposition activity in last year's second quarter, but up $11 million sequentially driven by increased revenue from several advisory assignments associated with Bed CCAR diagnostics. 
Other income declined $9 million from a year ago, reflecting lower 12 B 1 fees and the impact of real estate related disposition fees a year ago. 
Total expense rose $12 million year-over-year or 1%, driven primarily by revenue-related items including incentive compensation of AUM related expense which were largely offset by a decline in G&A expense. 
Compensation and benefits includes $65 million year-over-year of 7% due to higher headcount and incentive compensation, partially offset by the impact of a stronger dollar. 
G&A expense decreased $65 million year-over-year as a result of lower levels of marketing spend in the current quarter and the impact of elevated legal and regulatory expense in the last year's second quarter. 
Sequentially, G&A expense decreased $27 million from the first quarter, driven by lower levels of marketing spend. 
Second quarter G&A expense also included a previously disclosed $4 million product placement fees associated with the recently announced ABR refunding. 
Our second quarter as adjusted operating margin of 44.9% was positively impacted by the lower level of quarterly G&A spend. 
Looking forward, we continue to anticipate a higher more normalized level of G&A spend during the second half of 2015. 
We remain committed to using our cash flow to optimize shareholder value by first reinvesting in our business and then returning excess cash to shareholders. 
In line with that commitment, on June 12, BlackRock announced the acquisition of e-Quadrada, the leading independently manage infrastructure investment business in Mexico. We expect to close this acquisition in the fourth quarter of this year. 
During the second quarter, we also repurchased an additional $275 million worth of shares and refinanced $750 million of debt with a 10 year, $700 million euro denominated notes during a 1.25% coupon. This represented our first euro-denominated debt issuance better aligning our capital structure with our global business. 
Our consistent earnings growth and stable financial results reflect the benefits of our diverse platform, long term client partnerships and commitment to investment performance. 
Second quarter long term net flows were impacted by over $30 billion of low fee institutional index outflows, which massed almost $13 billion of active inflows driven by our improving Fundamental Equity performance, top-tier fixed income performance and strength in our multi-asset and alternatives businesses. 
BlackRock's global retail franchise saw long term net inflows of $11 million, representing 8% annualized organic growth for the quarter and 10% organic asset growth over the last 12 months. 
Flows were driven by continued strength in outcome oriented offerings, including unconstrained fixed income and multi-asset strategies. 
International retail net inflows have driven $3 billion replaced by strong flows into global unconstrained fixed income and the international equities. 
For the quarter, our leading European equities franchise generated nearly $2 billion of net inflows while our top quartile Asian equities franchise gathered more than $1 billion in new assets. 
Leadership in these areas contributed to BlackRock maintaining its year-to-date #1 ranking in cross-border mutual fund flows and its market-leading position in the United Kingdom. 
U.S. Retail inflows of more than $7 billion reflected strong fixed income flows [indiscernible] broad-based even in a period of rising rates. Despite a challenging quarter for industry close and U.S. active mutual funds, the depth and breadth of our franchise position BlackRock to continue to grow market share as we ranked in the top 5 U.S. Retail industry flows for the quarter and saw a strong demand for iShares from U.S. Retail clients. 
Globalize iShares a generated $11 billion of net new flows, representing 4% annualized organic growth for the quarter and 11% organic growth over the last 12 months. 
While the ETF industry experienced quarterly volatility amid uncertainty in global economic growth and central bank policies, year-to-date flows for both iShares and the ETF industry remain on record territory. IShares retained its #1 global market share position for the first half of the year and remains well ahead of the competition in global fixed income flows. 
iShares' equity inflows of $9 billion were led by flows into non-U.S. equity exposures including our ETA and Japan funds. 
We continue to see heightened investor focus on risk management as our currency hedge funds gather nearly $4 billion and our minimum volatility funds raised more than $2 billion during the quarter. 
iShares fixed income inflows are approximately $2 billion reflected flows into investment-grade corporate and emerging markets bonds, offset by outflows from treasuries and high-yield as investors reposition portfolio submits global rate movements. 
Our Institutional business experience $29 billion in quarterly long term net outflows, primarily driven by $35 billion of low fee index equity outflows from several large clients looking to reallocate, rebalance or meet their cash needs. 
As previously mentioned, these low fee index outflows had a limited impact on organic-based fee growth for the quarter. 
Institutional act of net inflows of more than $2 billion reflects the BlackRock's strong multi-asset and alternatives capabilities, offset by outflows and active equities. Multi-asset inflows of more than $4 billion were driven by solutions based funding, particularly in the insurance outsourcing space and continued strong demand for our life [indiscernible] target this year. 
Excluding return of capital of approximately $1 billion net inflows of $2.3 billion into core institutional alternatives were broad-based including alternative solutions, hedge funds, real asset and fund to fund offerings. 
Fundraising momentum continued with an additional $1 billion of illiquid alternative commitments raised in the second quarter, bringing total unfunded commitments a source of future net inflows to approximately $11 billion. 
Active equity outflows of nearly $2 billion resulted from a single sub-advisory redemption. 
Overall, BlackRock's second quarter reflected continued growth and stability in a more volatile environment and once again demonstrated the value of our highly differentiated and diversified platform. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Larry

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining the call. Our second quarter results were driven by client's continued trust in BlackRock to help them navigate an increasingly unpredictable financial and economic landscape. Uncertai
componenttext:
Thank you, Gary, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining the call. Our second quarter results were driven by client's continued trust in BlackRock to help them navigate an increasingly unpredictable financial and economic landscape. Uncertainty and anticipation around the first Fed rate hike in 9 years and concern related to the possible impact of a Greek Eurozone exits has led to persistent volatility in currencies and risk asset prices and global interest rates. 
Turmoil in China's equity market has reached unprecedented levels and the impact of intervention is yet to be fully understood by our markets. 
Falling commodity prices continue to put pressure in commodity exporting economies and both governments and corporations are being meaningful impacted by relative currency valuations. 
Constrained liquidity conditions are further magnifying market stress and volatility and I believe this elevated volatility will be going forward and I believe a part of the market. 
Both asset allocation to beta and alpha products and active management will be material drivers of returns for investors as they look to stay ahead of the changing market dynamics. Each of those are the drivers impacted client behavior in the second quarter as we saw a shift inflows from a range of high-performing active products and iShares position exposures while experiencing redemptions and low fee broad market index accounts. The investments we made in our platform over time, once again, has enabled BlackRock to create this highly differentiated Investment Solutions across asset classes, investment styles and geographies for our clients. 
At BlackRock, we are focused on delivering our best thinking and resources to our clients in our portfolio management teams. The BlackRock Investment Institute continues to lead that discussion as evidenced by our recent client call on Greece, which was attended by nearly 3,000 clients. This level of engagement by our clients is translating into an increase partnership with BlackRock to meet their investment needs and more clients throughout the world are looking for BlackRock and BlackRock's ideas, which we believe over a long cycle world will lead to a more share of wallet with these clients. 
Our internal culture of the information sharing and our relentless focus on risk management and performance in our active businesses is also enhancing BlackRock's ability to generate alpha on behalf of our clients and has resulted in strength across our active platform in performance and in flows. 
We've been very vocal about addressing the performance challenges in our active equity business. More than 3 years ago, we began upgrading our portfolio of management teams in our Asian in our U.S. fundamental active equity franchises. While we knew these changes will result in a near-term outflows and it would take our team many years to build the performance track record, we have the conviction based on past successes in revamping our active fixed income business and we kept our focus on the long term for our clients. 
We've bought a new portfolio manager who is currently responsible for more than $50 billion in assets and those managers are delivering on their objectives of generating high-quality risk-adjusted returns. 
We've not only hired new talent, we invested in technology, we elevated young talent from organic growth internally and lengthy global equity platform together to more effectively leverage the benefit of BlackRock. 
Since the respect to start dates, those managers have generated more than $2 billion in alpha for BlackRock clients. As a global firm, our objective is constantly outperform across our fundamental active equity platform and we've seen top performance in a range of products and regions. 
For the 3-year period, in the United States, our basic value fund is in 11th percentile. 
In Europe, our European value fund in the fourth percentile. And in Asia, our Asian Dragon fund is in the 16th percentile. 
In the second quarter, BlackRock saw improvement in our overall fundamental active equity performance figures with 78% and 61% of our AUM is above market or peer medium for the 1- and 3-year period. 
A strong long term track records for European and Asian equity franchises, as Gary discussed, is translated into flows raising more than $3 billion collectively in the second quarter. We still have work to do with our fundamental active team but we remain highly confident in the enhancements we made with the team that we have on board and we are very encouraged by the direction the business is being -- is headed. 
We also saw continued strength and generation of strong performance across our model or Scientific Active Equity platform. With 85% and 95% of our assets above benchmark or peer medium for 1- and 3-year period. 
In our interactive fixed income performance remains strong across the platform with 89% of our assets above benchmark or peer medium for the 3-year period, translating into continued momentum in flows. 
Again, it's a divergent and volatile backdrop in a challenged quarter for industry flows, BlackRock saw a total of net long term outflows of $7 billion. As $24 billion in net inflows into active and iShares strategies was offset by a $31 billion net outflows in these low fee institutional index strategies. 
Importantly, from a regional perspective, we saw $18 billion of net inflows in the Americas, offset by a net outflows of $25 billion from international clients who are more directly exposed to all the macro challenges that I discussed. 
As Gary discussed, focusing solely on organic asset flows, this is a critical component of our story. BlackRock generated long term organic base fee growth of 5% in the second quarter, reflecting the effectiveness of our differentiated business model and the combination of active and indexed on a single platform. As higher fee active flows drove robust revenue growth more than offsetting any revenue loss from our index outflows. 
In the second quarter, we saw sizable institutional index equity outflows driven by redemptions from international and official institutional clients due to a variety of cash needs and asset allocation decisions. A number of those outflows [indiscernible] from our institutional clients however, a bit offset by inflows by the same clients into BlackRock's active strategies. This is a very important component that we all shall be focusing on because as we discussed how we are building our unique business model, having the ability to have clients internally move assets around, whether it's from beta to active or active to beta, this allows us to continue to build deeper and more elongated relationships with our clients. 
Year-to-date, we desire to reallocate or address cash needs growth. 10 of our largest clients will redeem over $40 billion in institutional index assets. However, those same clients reinvested across BlackRock's active equity and fixed income multi-asset and also alternative strategies resulting in a positive net revenue impact for the firm. This demonstrates the value, as I said earlier, of a deep, strategic relationship we remained with our clients and validates strongly the strength of our solution-oriented business model. 
Second quarter active net inflows of $13 billion was driven by fixed income multi-asset and alternatives. 
We remain bullish on the opportunities in active fixed income as investors stock though a prolonged low rate environment searching for both yield and capital preservation. 
BlackRock generated $9 billion of active fixed income net flows across unconstrained high yield and total return strategies. 
The breadth and diversity of BlackRock's fixed income platform resonated in the second quarter as clients repositioned assets to achieve their investment goals. For example, our iShares high yield range saw net outflows of $1.8 billion in the quarter. The top performance we have in our active high yield franchise position us to capture $2.4 billion in net inflows. 
Alternatives was also a contributor to inflows and organic base fee growth in the quarter with $2 billion in net inflows. Alternative flows were led by alternative solutions where BlackRock is leveraging our differentiated models and our market position to construct outcome-oriented, multi-alternative portfolios for clients. 
BlackRock continues to build out our capabilities and infrastructure which is an important asset class that provides long term returns for our clients. 
In the second quarter, BlackRock announced the acquisition of Mexico's leading independent managed infrastructure investment firm. This acquisition advanced BlackRock's growth strategy all throughout Latin America obviously and including Mexico. And demonstrates our firm strong commitment to being a leader infrastructure investments. This is a continuation of the expansion of our infrastructure footprint in Mexico following the partnership with PEMEX  we announced in March. We also believe that building out our infrastructure platforms throughout the globe will make us a stronger and a more meaningful leading player in each local market and I believe it's very imperative to understand infrastructure investing for BlackRock will lead us to have a stronger mutual footprint as we grow our businesses worldwide and as I said repeatedly over years and years, we need to be a local firm in every country to build the trust and the strength as we become much more of a global platform firm. 
Technology remains a key area of focus and investment for BlackRock across all aspects of our business to enhance our investment process, client service, operational efficiencies and in unifying Aladdin technology platform. Aladdin generated 14% revenue growth year-over-year and Aladdin's growing value as a third-party platform positions BlackRock to invest a consistent and growing stream of revenues into improving our technology and expanding our offerings. And indeed, more and more clients are looking for risk management platforms as more investors need to go more global, the need for a moment robust Capital Market-focused technology platform is more imperative today than any other time and BlackRock Solutions Aladdin is becoming the driving risk management platform that more and more clients are looking to take on. 
The next step in the evolution of our business and ability to generate Alpha is the further harnessing technology that create innovative investment strategies for our clients. 
Over the last few years, we have become increasingly focused in becoming a data-driven company. Available data is exploding for the financial services industry and the true winners will be the firm that can extract information and package it into innovative solutions that generate alpha and outcomes for our clients. 
We recently hired Dr. Andrew Ang to be head of our new factor-based strategy group. Andrew joins us from Columbia business school and is an innovator, in fact, he's been based investing in portfolio construction. 
Technology is also going to become a more important part of our adopting to our evolving fixed income landscape. Throughout the quarter, there've been elevated focus on the state of the fixed income markets. There are a variety of dynamics set play including extraordinary monetary policy, increased bond issuance and regulatory reform which is contributes to reduce dealer inventories and lower turnover. 
While media attention has only spiked in recent months, BlackRock has been focusing on the issues for several years, how to enhance our training capabilities, how to enhance our portfolio construction risk management as well as being a thought leader on the topic. 
Going forward, it is important for all market participants to recognize we can't turn back the clock. We need to shift the dial to look forward and focus on solutions. BlackRock hopes to play a constructive role in helping our clients meet the challenges of today's market environment. 
We're also making recommendations on what the regulators and market participants can do to help improve the market ecosystem using a three-pronged approach including modernizing the market structure, addressing liquidity challenges at the product level and embracing product innovation, like fixed income ECS. 
As our clients investment challenges evolves so does the nature of the solutions they required. BlackRock's business model was deliberately built to deliver a multifaceted solution to our clients. And I don't believe any other investment firm can provide this multifaceted solution. 
BlackRock's ability to leverage these capabilities across a diverse global platform of active and indexed equities, fixed income, multi-asset and alternative strategies, all backed by Aladdin Analytics, risk management advisory capabilities, leading investment performance and client service, makes sense here, continues to result in improved outcomes for our clients and our shareholders. 
As always, I want to thank our employees for their continued dedication to working at -- to create a better financial future for our clients. 
With that, I'll open it up for questions.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015

I was hoping you might provide a little context, a little more context around various drives of revenue yield and base free growth between FX translation, AUM and flow mix shift and anything around the interior today you revenue yield as you head into Q3.

componenttextpreview: That will take half an hour answer though. Thanks, Gary.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Luke, we appreciate that you recognize that we are trying to do more appropriate disclosure for you guys. I think as we've talked about at length, what you guys -- the fee rates are constantly changing for us. It's a function of not only the organic
componenttext: Well, Luke, we appreciate that you recognize that we are trying to do more appropriate disclosure for you guys. I think as we've talked about at length, what you guys -- the fee rates are constantly changing for us. It's a function of not only the organic component which I think we are now demonstrating to everybody that is in our control and as we continue to see stronger growth in our higher fee retailing iShares businesses which carry higher fee rates on an organic basis, nothing changes in the world we were expecting overall theory to be accretive for us. In other words, obviously organic revenue growth in excess of organic AUM growth obviously helps that over time. However, we can't control things like divergent data and FX and obviously, as we've talked about over time, that will have an impact depending on where we go. And this quarter, it happened to help us but in other quarters, it has hurt us over time. As you know U.S. equities rose about 5% over the last year. In terms of U.S. benchmark AUM, that's about 32% of our equity-based fees, but in fact, it's the lowest fee geography for us at around 13 basis points. On an FX adjusted basis, year-over-year we saw EM in Europe down between 10% and 12% each, commodity is down close to 30% and those buckets are about another 1/3 of our equity bases fees and have an average fee raise significantly higher around 46 basis points. So in this case, year-over-year the overall fee rate was down about 0.6 points or roughly it's about 22 basis points due to that. But we benefited from some of that. In the current quarter also, we had better mix and we had an additional day, which basically helped the sequential fee rate up close to 0.9 basis points.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Luke, I would also add a little more color to what Gary just said. 3, 4 years ago, if we saw outflows in index funds, we may not have seen the active flows. What I think is really illustrative of all the hard work we've done over the last few years is we
componenttext: Luke, I would also add a little more color to what Gary just said. 3, 4 years ago, if we saw outflows in index funds, we may not have seen the active flows. What I think is really illustrative of all the hard work we've done over the last few years is we are now part of that dialogue and more and more clients that we are able to do this. As we suggested, a lot of them money in terms of the outflows were smart cash need driven by our clients for rainy day issues. And it's raining in some of the commodity-based economies. And so they're utilizing some of that. I think one of the things that is important to understand, I don't think the market understood how much was that were generated by all these large institutions internationally into the equity markets and in some cases, it's turned because they have needs for domestic needs. But we are seeing -- we have more increased dialogue on multi-assets in European equities, Asian equities, alternatives than we've ever had in the history of the firm. So the dialogue is more robust and certainly, a lot more complete and I think that's a component of the story. As Gary said, we can't control FX, we can't control divergent data. As Gary suggested, there has been quite a bit of divergent data in the commodity base up. Even in the last few weeks of June, first few weeks of July, we've seen more divergent data again. And so, we can't control that, but we certainly have -- and probably the key issue that we can control, deeper, more robust conversation with more clients worldwide.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then separately, now that ASCO has followed the sock and bagged up the approach of identifying specific asset managers as fees and favor of focus more productive activities, do you think that changing in the odds of how the FSB will ultimately a
componenttext: Okay, and then separately, now that ASCO has followed the sock and bagged up the approach of identifying specific asset managers as fees and favor of focus more productive activities, do you think that changing in the odds of how the FSB will ultimately approach regulation of the industry? Have you reaching a favorable tipping point or it's not time to relax yet?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would not relax. I don't think we should ever relax. Obviously -- let me just step back and say, a, if the market is a safer, stronger market and more people believe that the market is a great place, if regulation does add greater safety and soundness i
componenttext: I would not relax. I don't think we should ever relax. Obviously -- let me just step back and say, a, if the market is a safer, stronger market and more people believe that the market is a great place, if regulation does add greater safety and soundness in the minds of more and more investors, will be the biggest beneficiary. So our whole approach to regulatory conversation is somewhat different than with some the other leaders in the industry. We are -- we have traditionally -- and I continue to believe -- we will continue to do that tradition of having a deep dialogue with regulators using our international knowledge of what's going on and helping them try to understand what would be the best way to make it safer and sounder dialogue. So I don't  want to say the conversation is going to be more relaxed in the future because we need to still work with the regulators understanding what are the potential issues. As the world becomes more dependent on capital markets and that's happening now as of the ecosystem change with higher capital standards with banks and more and more enterprises, whether it's companies or individuals for using capital markets for raising capital, both debt and equity, we need a safe and sound ecosystem and if it needs to have it more supervision in some of the activities, we may be in favor of that. So we are going to work towards building a safer and sounder capital markets and we have enjoyed the relationships with the regulators and obviously, they don't have to listen to us. They are our regulators but by having what I would call a constructive dialogue, I believe it allows us to be part of the conversation and hopefully, this will lead to a better outcome.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Larry, first question of Fixed Income Markets for you guys. Obviously, we saw a lot of pretty big move. In the 10-year in the quarter, BlackRock's overall fixed income franchise did a pretty good job obviously handling this move. When you look out with re
componenttext: Larry, first question of Fixed Income Markets for you guys. Obviously, we saw a lot of pretty big move. In the 10-year in the quarter, BlackRock's overall fixed income franchise did a pretty good job obviously handling this move. When you look out with respect to clients response to prospect of high rates and now the movement seem so far, what are you hearing with respect to the overall allocations and just kind of the remix?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I find it humorous narrative of the -- there was a big article a couple of days ago or even caring about Garden Well all what's going to happen in fixed income. Hey, higher rates will lead to more players in fixed income not less. And I'll get into tha
componenttext: So I find it humorous narrative of the -- there was a big article a couple of days ago or even caring about Garden Well all what's going to happen in fixed income. Hey, higher rates will lead to more players in fixed income not less. And I'll get into that in a minute. Secondarily, 70% of our fixed income investors are pension and insurance companies. They're not influenced by market moves. They're trying to match the liability and that's the problem. The narrative -- they're not the players who are going flip around the interest rates. But the true component is, so many pension funded insurance have worked so hard by lower interest rates. In some cases, we know many insurance companies have actually a wide gap  -- the liabilities are longer than their assets -- so if we actually saw rising rate environment, this is quite additive to the balance sheet of insurance companies. If we saw a rise in interest rates, especially in the short end, the pension funds liabilities were look less onerous because it's all based on their funding rate and the capital rate they're used for the short term rates. In fact, many pension funds, if we saw a real spike in interest rates would -- de fees a lot of their pension liabilities. So higher rates actually is good for most long term investors and they're not particularly concerned about rising rates and are going to have money because the liability -- they bought these fixed interest items against certain fixed base liabilities and so they're not going to be that harmed on it. Now they may have accounting treatment differentials, but it's not going to be a big issue. It -- and for those who believe they want to navigate around the potentiality of higher rates, they're going to navigate from a long dated asset -- longer duration fixed income product to a shorter duration one. So -- and for those who still need to be in more long duration, but they're going to go into more of the unconstrained products that we are the leading driver inflows. So I -- I think people just forget -- they're implying that everybody's a hedge fund when higher rates means everybody's -- abandoning bond funds. Now some individuals, we're in fixed income because of safety and soundness. They don't generally whip them around either. They're generally holding them to maturity. But another thing, Alex, that I think that we are miscalculating, too, more and more moneys are going to fund contribution plans. More and more defined contribution plans are using target date types of structures and last I checked, we're living longer but more importantly, were all aging, at least I am. And as age, you're going to have a higher component of fixed income. So I would tell you fundamentally, demographically and all the things that were structurally seeing the way people are positioned, higher rates is not a bad thing for the fixed income market for the core investors.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. All makes sense. And just a follow-up, I guess, around the regulatory discussion. Given what it looks like more of an increased focus on liquidity and risk management on a product basis as opposed to hopefully a firm business, can you talk a littl
componenttext: Got it. All makes sense. And just a follow-up, I guess, around the regulatory discussion. Given what it looks like more of an increased focus on liquidity and risk management on a product basis as opposed to hopefully a firm business, can you talk a little bit about the opportunities that to monetize Aladdin's capabilities, your sales or licensing the product to your other asset managers, seems like that's going to be the area of focus for a lot of your peers?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are -- we probably have increased dialogue with Aladdin than ever before. Unquestionably higher regulatory supervision for activities would lead to more needs for risk management. Aladdin is one of the -- obviously, one of the risk management participa
componenttext: We are -- we probably have increased dialogue with Aladdin than ever before. Unquestionably higher regulatory supervision for activities would lead to more needs for risk management. Aladdin is one of the -- obviously, one of the risk management participants in the marketplace. Fiduciary standards are increasing. That has if -- people want to have better understanding of the risk embedded. As more and more managers embark in more -- in a larger, more robust global portfolio, they need better risk analytics and so all this is leading to greater utilization for platforms like Aladdin. Obviously, we have many great competitors. So I'm not trying to suggest we're not -- we're the only player, but we are in a very good position to have deeper, longer and probably more numerous conversations.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from Dan Fannon with Jefferies.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you discuss a little more detail about some the rebalancing that is occurring in the index products? Maybe the type of customers or the kind of discussion something you anticipate on going. It does seem I think your referenced most of it coming from t
componenttext: Can you discuss a little more detail about some the rebalancing that is occurring in the index products? Maybe the type of customers or the kind of discussion something you anticipate on going. It does seem I think your referenced most of it coming from the EMEA region, but just a little more color would be helpful.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think I referenced what the region. It's international, what I said. So it's -- we've had times -- if you go back 6 or 8 quarters, we've had big rebalancing then. People use beta as a placeholder of the tactical allocation. I mean, that's one seei
componenttext: I don't think I referenced what the region. It's international, what I said. So it's -- we've had times -- if you go back 6 or 8 quarters, we've had big rebalancing then. People use beta as a placeholder of the tactical allocation. I mean, that's one seeing people still don't understand. How much beta products are being utilized now for alpha. And there are many enterprises are tactically allocating whether overweighting, under weighting using beta products. And we see this more increasing everyday and in some -- and in the second quarter and part of the first quarter, we saw some of the big utilizers who had beta as an alpha component of their technical allocation for -- in some cases, they were taken profits and then the -- because of domestic issues, they are sitting with higher cash balances. Some of them may have been a little be more frightened of what's going on and some components of the world and are putting more and more money in cash. But more importantly, I would say most of the technical allocation was out of investment products, more into cash for the domestic issues. And this was not a performance issue. This was not moving money from BlackRock to another manager in most cases. It was moving from BlackRock to another BlackRock product and in most cases, the money was used for domestic needs or [indiscernible] needs.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then Gary, question on just the G&A outlook. It's been a volatile for you in the last few quarters. I guess, are we still expecting a ramp in the back half of the year? And could help kind of think of -- help us with some quantification around t
componenttext: Okay, and then Gary, question on just the G&A outlook. It's been a volatile for you in the last few quarters. I guess, are we still expecting a ramp in the back half of the year? And could help kind of think of -- help us with some quantification around that?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Look, I think as we look at the quarter, I think there's no question that our second quarter margin benefited from a lower level of G&A spend. If you recall last quarter, where many of you pointed out a year-over-year decline in our operating margin
componenttext: Sure. Look, I think as we look at the quarter, I think there's no question that our second quarter margin benefited from a lower level of G&A spend. If you recall last quarter, where many of you pointed out a year-over-year decline in our operating margin, we communicated to you that we felt our reported year-over-year margin comparisons really underestimated the operating leverage in the business and I think this quarter, frankly, we had the the opposite. I think there are 250 basis points of year-over-year margin expansion is overstated by a lower level of G&A spend that, frankly, is not likely sustainable. Look, part of a lower level of G&A spend in the quarter is better financial discipline in the current environment but part of it is frankly, simply expenses that came in lower than we expected. And I wouldn't -- I really wouldn't read too much entered into a trend basis, it was simply low G&A quarter relative to historical spend levels. Looking forward, I think I would say we continue to anticipate a higher, more normalized level of G&A spend in the second half of the year. And at this time, we're not intending to quote push out -- I think the words that you may have used, to reduce second quarter spend into the back half of the year.

Just comment on the fractionate you're getting in the financial advisory committee on the Core Series and then also commentary on institutional usage, including hedging and may be you mentioned that the substitute for fixed income, both cash trading and derivatives, increasing usage of ETF.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the exciting part of the ETF business is that as people become more aware of the benefits of ETF, they're coming up with other uses for ETF. So it has become not only a way to express your view on the market, but you can express it in a much more preci
componenttext: So the exciting part of the ETF business is that as people become more aware of the benefits of ETF, they're coming up with other uses for ETF. So it has become not only a way to express your view on the market, but you can express it in a much more precise way. So a lot of the flows that we're seeing are coming from this new usage. One of the new usage is, as you site, is that ETF become cheaper to use than futures. So we've seen a lot of institutions now as they become aware of that and we know as we talk about it, they are coming to us and asking us how we use ETF to better express their views of the marketplace. So we're seeing flows coming in from that as well as just the generic core and as you know, the 2 segments are certainly the buy and hold segment and we have introduced the core ETF for that and we're seeing growth in that to the tune of about $3.8 billion, which is a 7% organic growth in the quarter. So we're very excited as that continues to grow. But at the same time, we're seeing those or utilizing those for trading activities to express those reviews continue to grow as well. And a lot of that is in the high-yield area where they're expressing their views positive or negative, so you see inflows and that. And then you just see people that are actually looking at ETFs as a replacement also for their mutual fund business as well. So I think there is lots of opportunities in this. We're just beginning to scratch the surface in new uses for this. We continue to think that it's going to continue to grow going forward. And we want to be the innovator using ETFs to innovate to solve people's issues in their portfolios.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: A, we shared Department of Labor's goals for promoting better retirement security. This is one of the big issues that we've been stressing. I do believe retirement -- in inadequacy in retirement is going to be the big story in the coming years. I do belie
componenttext: A, we shared Department of Labor's goals for promoting better retirement security. This is one of the big issues that we've been stressing. I do believe retirement -- in inadequacy in retirement is going to be the big story in the coming years. I do believe the elevated savings rates that we're just seeing so far in the first 6 months possibly could be related to people starting to become more aware that they have an in adequate retirement plan. So we will be vigilant and outspoken on retirement issues. Look, related specifically -- your question, the need of investors are going to be differing. We all want good out -- good investment outcomes and we need to make sure that we, as an industry, provide client choice -- hopefully, client choice with low-cost. Cost is -- can't be primary because we have to be outcome heightened focus. Obviously, outcome-focused would cause -- is the emphasis and not the other way around. So the DLLs indicated interest for comments, so we submitted a commentary. We're going to have to wait and see how this all plays out. I don't think -- I don't believe we understand our habit of information to know how this will all play out. I think this will be evolving but we are working constructively with the DoL. And whatever they determine, we'll be able to daily in the coming quarters how that will play out for BlackRock and the impact. On the surface, it's going to have -- it has impact on BlackRock if it is as it is today because it impacts on some of our distribution platforms, but we'll be able to navigate that.

componenttext: Quick question on your retail business. Clearly, it's been a great performer for you guys for quite a long while now, your top 5. Just wondering at this point what additional opportunities do you see for that part of your business. And really I'm wondering, due to the fact that your share is seemingly gone up quite a lot, just wondering if incremental gains at this point might be a little bit harder to come by?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, A, 3 years ago, 4 years ago that we started talking about are building out a refill. 3 and 4 years ago, we started talking about building a stronger brand in the retail. 2 years ago, we integrated our retail and or iShares teams to be -- to offer mo
componenttext: Well, A, 3 years ago, 4 years ago that we started talking about are building out a refill. 3 and 4 years ago, we started talking about building a stronger brand in the retail. 2 years ago, we integrated our retail and or iShares teams to be -- to offer more outcome-oriented solutions that are instead of just product pushing and I think this has all created a more elevated position with our distribution platform. And I believe we have much more to go. We are still right behind other firms related to the IRAs. We still have deeper penetration to go with some of the big distribution platforms. And importantly, I believe because of our technology, because of Aladdin, I think we can provide better models to assisting our distribution partners and creating a better models, better advise and if we can continue to help our distribution platforms be better at what they do, combination of beta products and alpha products maybe with liquid alts, we should enjoy higher penetration of wallet. And I believe we're just beginning on that path.

componenttext: I think Larry, we'll get started here. First, just on active ETFs. I'm wondering if you guys have plans to launch some of your active products into a transparent ETF structure and also do you think your competition to more aggressively pursue this option just given the lack of nontransparent ETF options today?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've looked at this. We continue to look at this and right now, collectively, we're not sure that this is going to be a big opportunity in the marketplace. One of the benefits of ETFs is that the transparencies, the diversification and that enhan
componenttext: Yes, so we've looked at this. We continue to look at this and right now, collectively, we're not sure that this is going to be a big opportunity in the marketplace. One of the benefits of ETFs is that the transparencies, the diversification and that enhances the trading and the liquidity of these. So we're not sure that this is an opportunity we're going to pursue. We're thinking about it and we'll see how the market continues to evolve. So we're not ruling it out. But right now, we're not looking at that. And we view that as something that will compete more directly with mutual funds than it will than with normal ETFs.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would, once again, I think I said this in the past, I think there's way too much emphasis on this product -- I think -- we have said that we believe the ETF industry is going to go from a $3 trillion to $6 trillion industry. Activity ETF will be a compo
componenttext: I would, once again, I think I said this in the past, I think there's way too much emphasis on this product -- I think -- we have said that we believe the ETF industry is going to go from a $3 trillion to $6 trillion industry. Activity ETF will be a component of it, but it will be dwarfed by the industry's growth in traditional beta products. While you may see ETFs grow is really more based on model or smart beta products, where you're going to have tilts -- but I just -- I still don't see active ETF play a large role in the totality of the market and I agree with Rob. Yes, there is a growth, it's going to be a growth that's going to be taken away more growth from traditional mutual fund.

componenttext: But IRAs, we had very weak penetration 3, 4 years ago. We had very little visibility with many of the IRAs. And these are long -- we have to become a trusted partner. There some other firms that have had a long-standing, trusted relationship with these independent channels and I -- we are very pleased with the growth that we have in the RIAA channel in 2015. And I expect as I said earlier, we're going to build more share because I do believe we can become another trusted adviser to the channels.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ken Hill with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ken Hill with Barclays.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to follow up on one of the earlier questions. You guys have a really nice story to tell in a fixed-income market as ETFs play a greater role in supplying liquidity and what has been otherwise been a pretty ill-equipped corporate bond market. W
componenttext: So I wanted to follow up on one of the earlier questions. You guys have a really nice story to tell in a fixed-income market as ETFs play a greater role in supplying liquidity and what has been otherwise been a pretty ill-equipped corporate bond market. When you think about the dynamics of ETF playing a larger role longer-term, is there anything in there that you're perfectly concern about these passive products grows a percentage of the market? The thing that really increases the regulatory bull's eye here? And while it's still at a relatively small piece of the market now, do you think there is a natural cap on how much of the market ETFs can make up?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So our view of ETFs is different. And we think it actually enhances the liquidity of the markets because of the transparency. So you know what the underlying securities are so there's a market in those. And members a market of those as a whole. And in per
componenttext: So our view of ETFs is different. And we think it actually enhances the liquidity of the markets because of the transparency. So you know what the underlying securities are so there's a market in those. And members a market of those as a whole. And in periods of volatility, we've actually seen very little creation or redemption of any of those assets. We've actually seen the ETFs trade themselves. So we think it enhances the liquidity and therefore, we think this market could continue to grow. So we don't really -- I wouldn't agree with you on illiquidity in the corporate bond market. It's just that it's been more one-sided because it's more demand right now. So there really isn't the large secondary market. I don't call that a liquid, I call that over demand for yield securities because of the environment. So as interest rates rise, that will change a bit, but we think that, this has been providing good opportunity in the marketplace and just think of how large the fixed income market is and when you take a look at that, any percentage, any small percentage increase in ETFs so the the Fixed Income Markets is going to be very substantial and very large. So we're very bullish on the future of ETFs and how large they can grow relative to the fixed income market.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: But let's just talk about market dynamics a little bit. So ETFs are far more liquid and constructive versus mutual fund. And ETF throughout the day has a fire that matches with the seller. So every time you have a buyer matching a seller during the time,
componenttext: But let's just talk about market dynamics a little bit. So ETFs are far more liquid and constructive versus mutual fund. And ETF throughout the day has a fire that matches with the seller. So every time you have a buyer matching a seller during the time, the underlying assets are not traded. So this is one of the -- people don't understand -- when they talk about it, they just don't talk about the market dynamics. So for every buyer, there's a seller. You're not creating or redeeming the underlying assets. So for -- during a market opening, the ETFs is providing more liquidity. When you think about a mutual fund, a mutual fund in bonds is accumulating buyers and sellers throughout the day and at the final end of the day, they find out if they have to sell their underlying stocks -- our excuse me, bonds at the end of the day or the next morning because of the cash. So the ETFs actually is as Rob suggested, a provider of liquidity. It also creates the transparency of where the markets are and it's -- there's another surprise to me on the narrative. The narrative that you are able to transact bond sales and purchases in mass. By utilizing one stock, you're able to reduce the underlying assets and the need for a lot of sales of bonds, a lot of purchases bonds inter-day. And that's why a major component of why ETFs are additive to the liquidity and more importantly, they create transparency. And we've been telling the story for years. We've witnessed it. The Federal Reserve actually came up with a research report -- this is more related emerging market equities on the same concept that a provider liquidity. So we're still dismayed at the narrative.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to thank everyone for joining us this morning and for your continued interest at BlackRock. Once again, our second quarter highlighted the investments we've made over many years to enhance the differentiated platform that we have, a platform t
componenttext:
I just want to thank everyone for joining us this morning and for your continued interest at BlackRock. Once again, our second quarter highlighted the investments we've made over many years to enhance the differentiated platform that we have, a platform that's diverse, a platform that's global, a platform that can work in both alpha and beta products and I believe that as the second quarter is a good testimony of all that buildup. We continue to take a long term view and hopefully we're staying ahead of our clients needs and most importantly, as they suggested when we have 3,000 clients calling in to BlackRock Institute call, we are winning more and more hearts and minds of our clients which in my deepest hope that leads to a larger share of their wallet and we continue to do that, we'll continue to drive up performance for our shareholders in the landscape that is obviously very volatile. 
Everyone, have a good quarter, and we'll talk to you next quarter. Thank you.
